title: Civil rights campaigners bring 11th-hour challenge to enforce Boris Johnson to 'act within law' over Brexit
text:
Leading civil rights campaigners are bringing an 11th-hour legal challenge in a bid to "ensure the Government acts within the law" over Brexit.

The Court of Appeal will decide on Friday whether legal action brought by Liberty against Prime Minister Boris Johnson can be heard urgently.

The organisation announced the legal action against Mr Johnson in September, saying it was "gravely concerned" by media reports which suggested he intended to flout Brexit legislation.

The European Union (Withdrawal) (No 2) Act, commonly referred to as the Benn Act, requires Mr Johnson to seek an extension to the current Brexit deadline of October 31 if no deal is reached with the EU by Saturday.

"There is much confusion about whether the Government will comply with its obligations under the “Benn Act”," say Liberty.

(PA) Liberty have said More

"The Prime Minister’s lawyers have told us it will obey the law, but Boris Johnson himself has contradicted that claim."

The group added: "This will set an extraordinarily dangerous precedent.

"This is not a Brexit issue. No one is above the law – and if the Prime Minister breaks it, we’ll see him in court."

Liberty's challenge will be heard by three leading judges. A crowdfunder to support the case has raised £16,500.

(PA) Stephen Barclay told the committee today Mr Johnson would comply with the law More

If Court of Appeal judges conclude the legal action should be heard as a matter of urgency, they will go on to consider the full case immediately.

If the full hearing goes ahead, Liberty will ask for a declaration that the Prime Minister cannot take steps which would be likely to result in the EU refusing to agree to an extension, as required by the Benn Act.

The organisation, which is not affiliated with any political party, said it is "neutral" on Brexit and that the case is not concerned with how or whether the UK leaves the EU.

In recent weeks, Mr Johnson insisted the UK will leave the European Union on October 31, saying such comments as he would rather be "dead in a ditch” than stall Brexit.

Despite this, today Brexit Secretary Stephen Barclay said Mr Johnson will request an extension to the withdrawal date if no deal is passed by Saturday therefore complying with the Benn Act.

He told the Exiting the European Union committee, which was being chaired by Mr Hilary ​Benn who sponsored the Act in parliament: "I can confirm, as the Prime Minister has repeatedly set out, that firstly the government will comply with the law, and secondly it will comply with undertakings given to the court in respect of the law.
